newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila call loan rate flat despite huge payments.
newsitem.headline: Manila call loan rate flat despite huge payments.

text.p: Philippine inter-bank call loan rates were flat at an average of 10.53125 percent on Tuesday despite huge tax payments made by banks, traders said.
A foreign bank dealer estimated some 11 billion pesos were turned over to the government yesterday.
"There's so much liquidity," he said, due to maturing reverse repos. Banks have been reluctant to invest back in these bills because of the new 20 percent tax.
Volume in the inter-bank market narrowed to 4.930 billion from 8.7 billion pesos. Of 33 participating financial institutions, 19 were lenders.
Some 5.0 billion pesos were expected to be drained from banks this week due to the sale of ten-year bonds today, traders said.
Nevertheless, the market will remain liquid, traders said. "My guess is flat," one said, referring to the rates.
In the secondary market for T-bills, there was little activity since interest rates are expected to remain at current levels, a trader said.
"There is no indication interest rates would go up," the trader said, citing the liquid market.
Market attention was also focused on the auction of ten-year bonds later today where the coupon rate is expected at 14.5 to 14.75 percent versus 16.0 in the previous auction in September.
Dealers said banks were just buying short-term bills to meet clients' requirements.
A Reuter poll of eight instituions showed bid rates for three months ranged from 10.60 to 10.70; six months, 10.90 to 11.20; and one year, 11.40 to 11.60.
